explanation:
Required symbols and why:

- OS_rename: Direct callee of OS_mv. To determine MISRA for-loop compliance you must inspect callees for any for-loops whose behaviour could affect loop-counter usage (the rule counts the behaviour of functions called inside a for-loop body). Even though OS_mv has no for-loop, the callee implementation must be available for a complete analysis of the call path.

- OS_cp: Direct callee of OS_mv. Same reason as OS_rename — its implementation must be reviewed for any for-loops or side-effects that could interact with loop counters if used inside a for-loop in the caller.

- OS_remove: Direct callee of OS_mv. Include to inspect its implementation for any for-loops or modifications to objects that might be relevant to for-loop well-formedness when called from a loop context.

- OS_SUCCESS: Constant/macro used in OS_mv to test return values. Needed to fully understand the control flow of OS_mv (which branches are taken) so that any potential for-loops in callees that are only executed under certain return conditions can be analyzed.

- int32: The integer typedef used for the return type. Included so the analyzer knows the exact integer type/width/signing used for loop counters or values passed between caller and callees (relevant if any loop counters or loop-control flags in callees relate to types used here).

Notes: OS_mv itself contains no for-loop, so there is no direct violation in this function alone. The listed symbols are the minimal additional items required to inspect the functions OS_mv invokes (and the relevant control-flow constants/types) for any for-loops or side-effects that could be relevant under the MISRA for-loop well-formedness rule.
